Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2014 05:29PM Nel wrote: I had my first w/o and all was fine.  It was a matter of timing, getting me started on chemo before they could get a date to have the port put in. With IBC my onc was anxious to get me started on chemo.  I was told that chemo can wear out/collpase your veins and this is why the port is so helpful and recommended.  After surgery, nothing is recommended on the surgical side ie : blood pressure, blood draws, iv's so only having one side to use for IV can wear out veins sooner.  You do not want to have your veins collapse, it will leave few options for the future.  A couple of infusions w/o a port should be fine.  Check with your onc. Be well Nel

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2014 05:51AM Nel wrote: MrsM and others - tis the season for excess.  I have been struggling these last few weeks as well.  It has been a continual struggle to "get my game on" so to speak.  Everything seems to annoy me and require more energy  - physical and emotional than I have, a few have been on the receiving end of that frustration, not my finest moments and not really proud of them.   I have a particular lack of tolerance for those who "deny" I am sick and that cancer is eventually going to get me.  Yes I look good, work take care of life necessities, but the reality is at some point, this will end.  It is not my every thought, but don't tell me it is not the case when I need to talk.  I get their fear, concern for me - but sometimes I just need them  to be present with me for my moments.  I am getting better at who can tolerate and who cant.  To just be present when  needed, such a gift to receive and to give.  I too need to find an interest, other than my laptop and during the holiday season the Hallmark and Lifetime holiday movies.  (My not so guilty pleasure)  The acting is horrible, you can predict the ending, but none the less I can sit for hours. All that being said I am getting up and moving for my day  and then home to my movies. Be well Nel

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2013 03:52PM Nel wrote: Others have said much of what I would. But here goes anyway! My recent dx of stage 4 has remained with just a close group of friends and my ex. I made a decision not to share, didn't want the burden of all the questions etc. I do not even tell all the members of my posse when scans are coming up - "sometime in the next few months, need to discuss the date with doc" Or something like that. Also did not share with my children 19 and 15. I feel like when there is something for them to know, I will share, but right now there is nothing for them to know. I have my "posse" for support when I need it and felt like if others knew it would put more of a strain on me than I was willing to deal with. Treatment right now does not involve hair loss, so I can fly under the radar. Somewhat more fatigued, but seem to be able to manage that to a great degree. So I don't feel like I am lying all the time (for folks who are unaware) my response to how are you doing after the last year is "I feel well today and am doing well, and I think that is the most any of us can hope for!" Folks seem to go with that response. I spent many years in catholic school where lying to the nuns saved my sorry butt more than once. It is a skill I use when needed! Be well Nel

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2014 04:14PM Nel wrote: Memerel, I live south of Boston, near RI.  I was dx locally (biopsy etc)  and then moved all my treatment into Boston.  Dana Farber had a site at Faulkner in JP at the time, so it was a bit easier, but still, I needed to get out of the local folks.  My surgeon is at Faulkner Breast Center - Dr Farina Narkilis.  I can't say enough positive things about her.  Had an MX and the scar looks great.  No need for any touch ups.  And she was good, as should be expected but does not always occur, with my decision for no reconstruction. My onc was at Faulkner, now Dana Farber  I would follow him anywhere.  I did radiation locally and that was fine.  I hate the inconvenience of Boston, but it has been worth it for me to do the travel.  Dana Farber also has satellites at So Shore Hospital and Milford Regional.  Others may have different opinions.   Let me know if you have more questions. Nel

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2013 09:47AM Nel wrote: Jaybird, Sorry you are joining us here, but you will find great support. The port placement was fairly easy - home the same day with some aches, nothing a bit of advil didin't address.  You will be glad you have it. I did all the same chemos as well.  I did cut my hair short before it fell out - It helped me in the transition and I think my kids.  I only wore a wig a few times, baseball caps were my headcovering of choice.   A suggestion I saw on these boards - use a lint roller as you hair starts to fall out.  It catched the hair and oohh did it help the itch.  My dd and I still laugh about her walking into the kitchen and me  lint rolling my hair.  She was 13 at the time!  My kids already know I am a bit crazy  - so some of my behaviors during treatment just reinforced the notion.  So remember to laugh and help you son to laugh as well.  Think about getting a wig or scarves now.  Even if you don't use them much, you will have them when you need them. I had some nausea, no vomiting but they give you many pre-meds that it was manageable. I gained a few pounds, nothing outrageous.  Taste was a bit of an issue, but you will figure out what you want to eat and what you don't.  My onc told me to eat as healthy as I could, but not to make myself crazy if there were days whenmy appetitie was not great.  There were tears when I initially told my kids, they were 17 and 13, they both have friends whose Mom's have passed from BC.  But once I began treatment and they saw me getting thru most days reasonably well, they and I htink all of us felt better.  I was separated, but their dad did help with some things, driving to and from school or activites ondays when I just was really tired.  But i still shouldered most everything with them.  One of my treatment days withAC, I came home and took my son for his driving road test.  My ex couldn't take him, even tho that was the plan, he couldn't find his license!  So really it is amazing the strength we can muster for our children.    Your clinc should have books or resources for your son, I gave the schools a heads up just in case there were issues there.  Friends had meals deliveered or brought them in. I could have done it, but some days it was great just to not have to either tired or you just don't feel like eating and it is great to have something there to readily heat up. You will be able to do this.  I am sure like many of us you are are a strong independent woman,not used to taking any help from anyone.  That was the biggest adjustment for me.  Paid a cleaning lady, took meals when offerred and moved along.  Take the help when you need it and if there are specific things you need - ask .  Be wel and stay in touch. Nel

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2014 04:03PM Nel wrote: My onc uses neither.  A thumbs up after CT scans and big smile. The tumor found on my adrenal gland, just about a year ago, has been gone since the first CT scan after resuming treatment.  Like RonnieKays doc said, mine said as well that maybe if I had been able to stay on the Herceptin, the IBC would never have reappeared.  Who knows!   I consider my self NED, because I figure something is in there floating around and looking for its opportunity.  So for now I happily stay on tykerb and Herceptin. I think we have to take the post as one person's story.  I'd like to think we are all in this together, happy for those doing well and supporting those facing challenges.  We all wish it could be us telling that story.  For some of us it may be and for others it will not.  It just reminds me of how fickle cancer can be. be well nel
Posts.Title: thoughts about difference between remission and NED reader123 leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2018 10:25AM Nel wrote: Just found this thread.  I have been a uniboober for 6 years, I am now 64.  I did not do reconstruction as it was recommended that I wait a year following MX as I had inflammatory breast cancer.  A year later - elective surgery - no way - my body had been through enough.  I am a B cup ( so I know this makes it easier) and I seldom wore a bra prior to cancer.As I tell my daughter I went to college when we were burning our bras not wearing them! RE: dressing  The cooler seasons here in the northeast are easier. Sweaters, scarves, vests   I have also gravitated to loose fitting tunic style tops    Summer presents a bit more of a challenge - but seldom wear a bra even then.  Again, tunic style tops.  I have had some comments and stares.  My attitude is the hell with anyone else - I am happy and comfortable in my own skin.  That being said, I do work and am more cautious about how I present in a professional environment.   I do have a foob, but not sure I could even tell you where it is right now. To make it all more interesting - divorced and trying to date LOL.  So far it has not been an issue   This is a tough one - lots of things to consider etc.  It is finding what is right in your new normal  Best Nel

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2018 05:08PM Nel wrote: Mine was dx with an adrenal biopsy.  Fine needle aspiration.  Not particularly difficult.  My onc did the biopsy to make sure her2 status and er and pr were the same as initial dx.  This information informs treatment options.  The status of these can change and if you and your onc are not aware - you may not be getting the most appropriate treatment. Best, Nel
Posts.Title: Anyone diagnosed with adrenal gland mets? duchessoftea Stilts

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2019 11:46AM Nel wrote: Stilts, Biopsy was pretty simple. No to very minimal discomfort following  Biggest issue was having to lay perfectly still on the table during the biopsy.  I have a hard time sitting still lol I wanted the adrenal gland removed, my onc was not for it, MBC being systemic and treating it systemically and all that   I was going to get a second opinion, but my first round of treatment got me to Ned for 3.5 years, so I dropped it.  I have a new onc now, who has said she would support, but cancer has also spread to my perionatal (sp) cavity lymph nodes, so even if I had adrenal removed I would have to stay in treatment.  The good news is that I have been MBC for 6 years and this is the first time it has gone past my adrenal gland I certainly wish it hadn't but what ever it is doing is very slow moving  I will take that Keep me posted Nel
Posts.Title: Anyone diagnosed with adrenal gland mets? duchessoftea Stilts

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2018 09:35PM Nel wrote: I was dx with adrenal gland mets as well 6/2013   It is no typical but we are out there.!!    er/pr-, her2+   First round of treatment was Herceptin/tykerb.  Had immediate response and went 3.5 years NED.  Showed up again in April 2017.  Treatment is now Herceptin ( a Her2+ treatment) and xeloda.   Stable at first scan in August, next scan is in 3 weeks.  Fingers crossed!!  When initially dx, I wanted adrenal gland removed, from my perspective -immediate solution.   My onc recommended against it.  He described the adrenal gland as a fishnet that was catching the cancer cells before they got any where else in my body.  I went with his recommendation and so far it seems to have worked,no mets anywhere else!    Be well Nel
Posts.Title: Anyone diagnosed with adrenal gland mets? duchessoftea Stilts

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2018 09:35AM Nel wrote: Little stinker on my adrenal is going - so says recent PET Scan. Changing up treatment. Transferring to new guy.  They have spoken I will meet new guy on May 14th and begin new treatment    Have to follow up with one of them today to find out what option they are recommending   It is either Herceptin, pertuzamab and tdm1 or Herceptin , pertuzamab and navelbine   Current onc tells me not to worry, little bugger is growing slowly and adrenal gland is doing its job.    Many years ahead of me he says - so that is what I am going with    Let's hope new onc feels the same! Hope all are well  Nel

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2013 02:40PM Nel wrote: Tera, I am on tykerb/Herceptin since August. No hair loss on this combo. The diarrhea seems to be set off by different foods for everyone. For me it seems to be Chinese food is waaaay off the list of things I can eat. I am figuring out how to manage the bouts of needing a bathroom with immodium and am finding a balance between being constipated, too much imoduum, and diarrhea, not enough. It is taking a bit of tinkering. That being said, nothing that has kept me from leaving the house which seems to be my onc's criteria for a significant problem. I have had a few issues of skin near my nails splitting, but am using Udderly Smooth and all is good again. Not sure how the xeloda adds or changes things , but the tykerb Herceptin combo is pretty manageable at this point. Some fatigue, equals more naps and to bed a bit earlier. MY QOL is good, working, kids, house and time with friends, just all at a somewhat different pace. Hope this helps. Be well nel

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2013 08:25PM Nel wrote: My kids were teens when I was dx.  Like others I  didn' t tell them until I had a plan I had agreed on with my onc.  It was a very long 2 -3 weeks.  They were 17 and 13.  We sat them down together, I am separated from their dad, but he was here as well.  I wanted them both to hear the same thing at the same time.  And I wanted their dad to be here and hear what I said so he could support it down the road.  My dd has been angry now that she realizes I had a dx for a couple of weeks before I shared.  My explanation - I didn't want them to worry needlessly and wanted to wait until I had a definitive plan.  Right or wrong, that was the decision I made and we couldn't go back.  Maybe your adult children will be upset, maybe they won't, everyone's reaction is different.  But hopefully they will respect that you have the right to make the decision that works for you.  This also gives you time to adjust yourself - a huge hurdle before you take on the world! Be well Nel

Posts.Content: May 27, 2013 09:50PM Nel wrote: I have been taking celexa for several year, pre DX, due to menopause symptoms  - -irritable, yelling at almost anything and everything and it has been a huge help.  I had used ativan in the past as needed, when my parents were dying and when my son was struggling with substance abuse issues.  Did n't get addicted to the ativan and stopped when I decided I no longer needed, but it was not a daily med.  When I was dx with BC, my doc added buspar.  There was just too much on my plate, cancer, marriage dissolving , son still struggling.  I HATE to rely on anything! So this was a huge leap for me.  I also had a therapist, he urged me to see a psychaitrist for the meds, my internist was just sort of guessing in the dark.  It will give you a place to work from, lift you up a bit for the time being.  Use a psychialtrist - best recommendation I received. Be well Nel

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2016 09:12PM Nel wrote: I am living with MBC (3 + years) and still go in and out of sadness, depression, anger, anxiety and acceptance.   I don't believe it is a straight line from anger to acceptance.  It depends on the day, how I feel, how soon my scan is coming up etc.  But in the interim - I work, enjoy my children (18 and 23), my friends, travel, nap - there are a lot of naps,  and am planning for my future - retirement next year.   Sooner than I anticipated, but I don't see the purpose in waiting.  I speak and advocate, when the opportunity presents, on the need for research for MBC.  We are dying, 113 a day, so while I also have a smile on my face and am moving thru life - the knowledge is ever present that I, we, are living compressed lives.  Nel age 62

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2015 02:06PM Nel wrote: I am cautious as well, and think we all need to keep our ears to the ground. But a conversation we should all be having with our docs. When to stop, when to continue, what do we want our QOL to be at the end. I receive Herceptin every 3 weeks, tykerb pills at home each evening. This is considered palliative care, since I am stage 4 and not curable. Even tho I have been NED for 2 years (minus a few days!) The cost to my insurance company $4000 a month for tykerb and approx. $25,000 every 3 weeks for Herceptin. And what is tha a year, I do not have enough fingers, LOL. I am what insurance companies refer to as "catastrophic longevity" I intend to remain a catastrophy for my insurance company for many years to come. My QOL is very good and that will be the deciding factor for me. Gentle day Nel

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 08:08PM Nel wrote: lovehertons, I haven't read your new here posts, but I am going on Friday for #9 of herceptin/taxol treatment.  I have had minimal side effects. No nausea, no vomiting, minimal diarrehea  Most of my hair has fallen out, my mouth has that metal taste and I have become a bit more fatigued over the course of treatment. My onc tolde me SE     partulalry fatigue would be cumulative. We all respond differently but  So far it has been managable, the fatigue thing has been the most difficult for me as I am still working (not day of treatment) and have two children ,tho older 13 and 18 that need some oversight.  The good news is that my cancer has respondedwell.  I am going into surgery in February with the cancer shrunk to barely noticable at this point.  I hope  the best for Di in the coming weeks.  Gentle hugs Nel

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2013 05:11PM Nel wrote: Yogagirl, I worked thru treatment, but have a job that is 30 very flexible hours and can work from home on the days I wish to. I manage a small non-profit.  So the situation was all in all ideal. So when folks are impressed that I worked, I remnid them thatmy situation was different than most. I had treatment on Fridays and then would be low key during the weekend.  If it was a day I was tired, I would work from home and perhaps nap for a bit during the day.  Others are right, you need to decide what will work best for you.  The benefit for me was keeping my mind on something other than cancer - that was the biggest benefit for me.  I did herceptin/taxol for 12 weeks, surgery and then 4x3 weeks of the A/C.  it depends on your job, and the expectations. You will know what works for you. Be well Nel
